00025 /*
00026  * Unix domain sockets are used for stream based connected sessions between processes on the same machine
00027  * --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00028  * - UNIX domain sockets use the file system as the address name space. This means you can use UNIX file permissions to control access to communicate
00029  *   with them.  I.e., you can limit what other processes can connect to the daemon -- maybe one user can, but the web server can't, or the like.
00030  *   With IP sockets, the ability to connect to your daemon is exposed off the current system, so additional steps may have to be taken for security.
00031  *   On the other hand, you get network transparency. With UNIX domain sockets, you can actually retrieve the credential of the process that created
00032  *   the remote socket, and use that for access control also, which can be quite convenient on multi-user systems.
00033  *
00034  * - IP sockets over localhost are basically looped back network on-the-wire IP. There is intentionally "no special knowledge" of the fact that the
00035  *   connection is to the same system, so no effort is made to bypass the normal IP stack mechanisms for performance reasons. For example,
00036  *   transmission over TCP will always involve two context switches to get to the remote socket, as you have to switch through the netisr, which
00037  *   occurs following the "loopback" of the packet through the synthetic loopback interface.  Likewise, you get all the overhead of ACKs, TCP flow
00038  *   control, encapsulation/decapsulation, etc. Routing will be performed in order to decide if the packets go to the localhost. Large sends will
00039  *   have to be broken down into MTU-size datagrams, which also adds overhead for large writes. It's really TCP, it just goes over a loopback
00040  *   interface by virtue of a special address, or discovering that the address requested is served locally rather than over an ethernet (etc).
00041  *
00042  * - UNIX domain sockets have explicit knowledge that they're executing on the same system. They avoid the extra context switch through the netisr,
00043  *   and a sending thread will write the stream or datagrams directly into the receiving socket buffer. No checksums are calculated, no headers are
00044  *   inserted, no routing is performed, etc. Because they have access to the remote socket buffer, they can also directly provide feedback to the
00045  *   sender when it is filling, or more importantly, emptying, rather than having the added overhead of explicit acknowledgement and window changes.
00046  *   The one piece of functionality that UNIX domain sockets don't provide that TCP does is out-of-band data. In practice, this is an issue for almost
00047  *   noone.
00048  *
00049  * In general, the argument for implementing over TCP is that it gives you location independence and immediate portability -- you can move the client
00050  * or the daemon, update an address, and it will "just work". The sockets layer provides a reasonable abstraction of communications services, so it's
00051  * not hard to write an application so that the connection/binding portion knows about TCP and UNIX domain sockets, and all the rest just uses the socket
00052  * it's given. So if you're looking for performance locally, I think UNIX domain sockets probably best meet your need. Many people will code to TCP
00053  * anyway because performance is often less critical, and the network portability benefit is substantial.
00054  *
00055  * Robert N M Watson
00056  * --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00057 */
00058
